Happy 1st Day of School Eve! Let’s kick off this year with some recent GOOD NEWS about our AP (advanced placement) exams taken in May…
• LNC AP exam performance reached an overall proficiently level of 81.5% with 519 test testers out of 553 students enrolled in AP classes! (AP exams are scored 1-5 with students who score a 3, 4 or 5 considered “proficient” in that college level subject matter)
• In 3 AP classes (Studio Art II, Studio Art Drawing, Biology) our students achieved 100% proficiency!
• In 3 more AP classes (Chemistry, English Literature and US Gov’t) our students reached 90% proficiency!
• 9 of our 15 AP subjects were at least 20% higher than the national average!
Congrats to our students and their teachers on this impressive success, especially considering they completed the end of the year in a remote learning setting!

At the annual YCI Eagle Awards, LNC’s club was recognized as “Club of the Year.” The award is given to a club that has displayed excellence in club programming, leadership, community service, and diversity. Out of 158 clubs, our club was recognized for its weekly meetings, bi-monthly leadership meetings, focused student-led presentations, and a diversity of the student body represented with middle and high school students.

Also at the Awards, 8th grader Maeve Yarbrough was recognized with the OCL (Outstanding Christian Leadership) Award, and club leaders Summer Hull, Cole Smith and Ethan Herron were OCL finalists. The OCL recognizes students who display Christ-like character and an aptitude to make a difference through the Gospel. Congratulations to the YCI club members and their staff leader, Mr. Herron.

Join Mrs. Tedder for the third selection for First Chapter Friday. This week's selection is "Nowhere Boy" by Katherine Marsh.
"Fourteen-year-old Ahmed is stuck in a city that wants nothing to do with him. Newly arrived in Brussels, Belgium, Ahmed fled a life of uncertainty and suffering in Syria, only to lose his father on the perilous journey to the shores of Europe. Now Ahmed's struggling to get by on his own, but with no one left to trust and nowhere to go, he's starting to lose hope.
Then he meets Max, a thirteen-year-old American boy. Lonely and homesick, Max is being bothered by a bully at school, he doesn't speak a word of French, and just can't seem to do anything right. But with one startling discovery, Max and Ahmed's lives collide, banding the boys together to help Ahmed survive."

post_text: Congratulations to LNC senior Anna Gartner for becoming a National Merit Scholarship Finalist! The National Merit Scholarship Program is in its 65th year and is a highly competitive and prestigious scholarship program with less than one percent of all U.S. high school seniors achieving Semifinalist status. Criteria is based on the PSAT, which all juniors nationwide take in the fall. National Merit Semifinalists are announced the following fall when those juniors are seniors and those students that go on to become Finalists are informed in the early spring. Over the next few months Finalists will be notified whether they achieve National Merit Scholar status and receive the associated scholarship. The National Merit Scholarship Program is in its 65th year and is a highly competitive and prestigious scholarship program with less than one percent of all U.S. high school seniors achieving Semifinalist status. Criteria is based on the PSAT, which all juniors nationwide take in the fall. National Merit Semifinalists are announced the following fall when those juniors are seniors and those students that go on to become Finalists are informed in the early spring. Over the next few months Finalists will be notified whether they achieve National Merit Scholar status and receive the associated scholarship. Good luck, Anna and great job on this incredible accomplishment!

On February 19, students at all three schools participated in a Mix It Up at Lunch event. Students sat with one or more peers that they did not know or do not normally sit with. Before and after the event, students participated in classroom activities that encouraged them to think about friendships, social cliques, empathy and acceptance. During lunch, teachers and students presented groups of students with questions to discuss. While some students expressed discomfort with sitting with people they did not know, many expressed positive reactions to stepping out of their comfort zones. A huge thanks to the teachers and student leaders who put this event together!

post_text: Collaboration with peers is a great way for students to learn. In these photos French I students (8th grade) worked together with one student hustling out into the hallway to view a French sentence and then returning to his or her group and speaking the sentence. Then, another student wrote what was said and a third student illustrated it to show the meaning of the sentence. The sentences pertained to Le Tour de France and the verb "aller" meaning "to go" which is the class's current grammar and culture focus. This activity was timed, adding another layer of urgency and fun!
